Are you ready for 🤖ROUND TWO?⁠
⁠
This time the action will take place at @draughtindustries in the Hudson Valley this Sat, Dec 10th. Foeder Force is a 2-way collaboration with Proclamation Ale Works in Warwick, RI.⁠
⁠
We took the standard collaboration playbook and flipped it on its head to make it a true 2-way partnership. After deciding on the recipes, we exchanged house cultures from our respective oak foeders. We used their beer culture to ferment our foeder-aged cider, while they took our cider culture to ferment their foeder aged beer.⁠
⁠
The fun starts at 2 PM, but the draught system will be pouring the collaboration all day + 4 other beers from @proclamationale + 3 Graft Ciders.⁠
⁠
🥇CIDER EXPLORERS: Bring your One Year Cider Coin for a Graft Cider on us!⁠
⁠
#FoederForces #BarrelAged #ProclamationAle #DraughtIndustries #Beacon #HudsonValley #NY #GraftCider

WE BET YOU ALREADY KNOW that each cider in the Book of Nomad series has a story to accompany each flavor. Catch up below to see where Dog and Nomad have been exploring this fall season.⁠
⁠
𝐂𝐡𝐚𝐩𝐭𝐞𝐫 𝟏: 𝐌𝐨𝐭𝐡 𝐭𝐨 𝐚 𝐅𝐥𝐚𝐦𝐞⁠
On a densely wooded planet, Nomad and Dog are taking a leisurely walk on the forest floor. Swatting away some pestering moths, Nomad notices that their numbers are only growing stronger. Before long they are swarmed by huge moths with 8 foot wingspans, which nip and harass Nomad and Dog as they break into a full sprint. Nomad trips and falls on a twisted root, and when Dog is trying to help her up, they are surrounded, bound in silk, and captured.⁠
⁠
𝐂𝐡𝐚𝐩𝐭𝐞𝐫 𝟐: 𝐀𝐬𝐡𝐞𝐧 𝐅𝐚𝐢𝐫𝐲⁠
Nomad awakens to find herself in the moths’ glittering nest in the tree canopy. She is greeted by a glowing grey woman with Lepidopteran wings, who explains that she is the guardian fairy of the moths. Nomad learns that human colonizers have been decimating their numbers – disorienting the adults with flashbangs and kidnapping their caterpillars. Nomad offers up her services as a negotiator to see if any sort of concessions can be made with the humans.⁠
⁠
𝐂𝐡𝐚𝐩𝐭𝐞𝐫 𝟑: 𝐂𝐚𝐩𝐭𝐢𝐯𝐞 𝐀𝐮𝐝𝐢𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐞⁠
Reaching the human encampment, Nomad tries to reason with the superintendent, who boldly laughs off her concerns and assures that he and his settlers would never cease harvesting and boiling the caterpillars for their silk and flesh. After being relayed the message, the moths and ashen fairy decide that they must make a show of force. At dusk, they return to the camp and capture the humans by weaving silk strands around them. Afraid of being left for dead, their entangled leader begs for their lives and vows a swift withdrawal if they are shown mercy, and the moths oblige.⁠
⁠
story by @CalebLukeLin⁠
photo by @Kristen_Edgell⁠
#GraftCider #SourCider #FutureCider #HudsonValley #Newburgh #NewYork #BookofNomad #NordicMead #StoryTime #GlutenFree

Crushing on this season's hottest flavor: 🔥Cranberry 🍊Tangerine 🍦Dreamsicle! Get cozy by the fire with a glass of this delicious cider.⁠

At Graft Cider, the past year was all about making a difference. First, we donated 10% of our 🌎️Green Planet Cider Series profits to non-profit agencies that protect and restore the earth, giving them 🤑$15K in total! As if that wasn't enough good news for people who care about sustainability, on top of this donation, we also gave an extra 💪$2K as part of our @BRAVENOISEBEER project to @BeerKulture - which strives towards creating diverse opportunities within the craft beverages industry.⁠
⁠
We created 🍎32 different cider styles, 🍻7 of which were made with fellow breweries. In addition, we ventured to the hills of Vermont to 🧀wash some cheese, and believe it or not, 🙌we made some pretty good progress on our new production facility. ... All put together, it's safe to say: that Graft 2022 has been anything but boring (or still!).⁠
⁠
Our heartfelt thanks to the 💖Cider Explorers for going on a flavorful journey in search of sour cider throughout 2022! Cheers to a year full of delicious discoveries.⁠
⁠
photo by whoever has the gold makes the rules @kristen_hunter_photographer⁠
#GraftCider #HappyNewYear #LookBack #SourCider #FutureCider #ExploreCider

Shared Universe x @eviltwinbrewingnyc⁠
⁠
We teamed up with Evil Twin Brewing out of New York City to create CEREMONY, a two-way collaboration.⁠
⁠
Our side of the collaboration is a 🍋Yuzu 🍾Champagne 🍎Cider that tastes like popped natty Champagne, freshly squeezed yuzu, and ceremonial Japanese tea.⁠
⁠
✅Gluten Free - 6.9%ABV⁠
⁠
We co-fermented our cider with wild and champagne yeast on top of a yuzu emulsion and 🍇Riesling grape skins sourced from @brotherhoodwinery. After aging, we steeped a tea with 🌿silver needle white tea and 🥔ginger and added some more 🧃white grape juice to the final concoction before cranking the carbonation up on this for a sparkling beverage to bring in the new year.⁠
⁠
🍺 @eviltwinbrewingnyc created a champagne blonde ale that’s brewed with champagne yeast & conditioned on yuzu, riesling grapes, ginger, & white tea⁠
⁠
Both are available near you soon!⁠
⁠
#SharedUniverse #Ceremony #YuzuChampagneCider #SourCider #FutureCider #ExploreCIder #GraftCider #EvilTwin

Get ready to lose your minds this February because we are releasing a cider so sought after that even we here at Graft don’t get any to take home.⁠
⁠
This uber-exclusive - super rare cider is none other than our Smuggler barrel-aged series. We are still drooling over the thimble we were allowed to sample last week to create the tasting notes.⁠
⁠
This year we collaborated with our neighbors, @thespiritslab , who dropped off four freshly dumped Bourbon barrels made from Missouri Oak and charred to a level 4. Each barrel still had roughly 5 gallons of spirits trapped inside, which we topped off with French bittersweet apple juice and fermented with White Wine & Champagne yeast. ⁠
⁠
The final product tastes like nectar from the Gods, pouring a deep brown, with notes of classic Bourbon, vanilla, and caramel swirling together with a leathery apple finish. ⁠
⁠
This cider will NOT be making its way into distribution. The only way to get your hands on it, is to be a Cider Club Explorer. 

Cheers!

Dog and Nomad have been globetrotting this winter season, bringing you the flavors of new places along their journey! Each cider in The Book of Nomads series has a story to tell - learn what they've discovered so far.⁠
⁠
🔥🦕Ch 1: Warmth in Winter⁠
⁠
On a wintry world, Nomad and Dog are introduced to a greenhouse civilization occupied by an assortment of strange aliens. With blistering winds howling outside, they tour the magnificent halls of crops and greenery. As the weather worsens outside, an alarm sounds, announcing that a humongous hailstorm is headed their way. As the residents begin to take shelter, hunks of ice suddenly pelt the city structure, shattering glass and sending the temperature plummeting in sections of town.⁠
⁠
🧵🪡Ch 2: Stitch by Stitch⁠
⁠
Huddled in the bunkers down below, the civilians and city leaders discuss with Nomad emergency actions that they can take to rescue themselves from the imposing freeze. Nomad and the warm-blooded aliens venture back out into the cold to fetch supplies, and the artisans and sewist begin to stitch together great quilted sheets to temporarily repair the broken panes of glass. Soon, every able body is hard at work in order to save the city from the deep chill.⁠
⁠
🌞🤝Ch 3: Patchwork Sanctuary⁠
⁠
With the completed quilts, Nomad leads some of the best flying and climbing aliens back out to the greenhouse and they begin to install the patchwork repairs. Little by little, they are able to close up the holes in the walls and ceiling, providing relief to citizens. Later in the day, the sun finally comes out, and the wide array of creatures are able to bask in the comforting warmth.⁠
⁠
story by @CalebLukeLin⁠
photo by @Kristen_Edgell⁠

🌷Introducing the first cider in our Spring Sake series, THIEVING FROM THIEVES. ⁠
⁠
Thieving from Thieves is a 🍓Strawberry 🫘Tamarind 🍶Sake 🍎Cider that tastes like Strawberry Sour Strips, Candied Cardamom, Tamarind Chews, and Earthy Ginger.⁠
⁠
This cider was fermented using NY Apples, paired with sweet-tart tamarind paste, spicy ginger, and kaffir lime leaves for bright citrus notes. Finishing off this blend are aromatic cardamom seeds and sake yeast which round out the pallet. ⁠
⁠
6.9% ABV - GLUTEN FREE⁠
⁠
Thieving from Thieves should be making its way into stores near you now. 🧐Double-check by using our cider finder on our home page. Cheers!⁠

BOOK OF NOMAD | TINKER TOYS⁠
⁠

We then add a hint of vanilla bean warmth followed by traditional 🍶Japanese Sake yeast for an exceptionally smooth finish.⁠

This cider will be featured in our April Cider Explorers box and will make its way into the market near you in a month. Cheers!⁠

Sometimes making cider can get a bit messy (swipe to see), but it's all worth it when the final product tastes this good!⁠
⁠
We teamed up with our friends over at @thevalefox to distill our cider base into Brandy. Vail Fox distilled the cider until the liquid reached 140-proof. From there, we soaked four of our barrels in Brandy. Fresh pressed juice was blended into the spirit-soaked barrels, which were left to ferment spontaneously.⁠
⁠
Native Applejack tastes similar to French farmhouse cider. Buttery, earthy and funky. 6.9% ABV⁠
⁠
This cider will be featured in April's Cider Explorer box and will be released into selective markets within a few weeks.⁠
⁠
⁠
#Native #NativeApplejack #GraftCider #ValeFox #CiderExplorer #ExploreCider #sourcider

Falling Flowers | Floral Saison Yeast Fermented Cider⁠

We were inspired by Forest and Main's love for saisons and the lushness of spring.⁠
⁠

Keep an eye out for NEW Field Day. Not only did the artwork get a makeover, so did the cider inside.⁠
⁠
Field Day is now a 🍓Strawberry 🍷Rosè 🍎cider. ⁠
⁠
We wanted to create a fruity rosè that stands out from the rest which is why we opted to not only use fruit. To give Field Day an earthy and deep flavor, we incorporated flowers like hibiscus, rose hips, and rose petals in addition to Strawberry, Rhubarb, and Orange. Adding more than just fruit adds complexity and depth to the blend. ⁠
⁠
We also opted to remove an ingredient from the blend, rooibos. Rooibos imparts vanilla notes and creates a tonic body.  We were looking to create a flavor more akin to a zingy, snappy cider that's reminiscent of natural wine.⁠
⁠
Also, we recently purchased an industrial grinder and have been having the time of our lives processing and incorporating whole ingredients (swipe left).⁠
⁠
We think you will be able to taste the difference; we certainly can.⁠
⁠

We wanted to create a cider that captures the essence of tiki culture and cocktails, with complex and balanced flavors that stand out. 🍍⁠

To achieve this, we used a double layering process of both fermenting and sweetening the cider with tropical fruits. At Graft, we’re always pushing the boundaries of ingredient innovation and sustainable agriculture. So when we teamed up with @botanistandbarrel, we knew we had to try something daring: fermenting an entire blueberry bush! 🌳 ⁠
⁠
#GraftCider #BotanistandBarrel #Collab

Let's talk about 🌳The Whole Bush.⁠
⁠
Featured in July's Cider Explorer box and out in markets near you soon-ish is The Whole Bush, a collaboration with @botanistandbarrel , a natural cidery/ winery from North Carolina.⁠
⁠
The Whole Bush is a Blueberry Bush Cider that clocks in at 6.9% ABV, is gluten-free, and has 3g of sugar. It's subtle, soft, and blueberry.⁠
⁠
We've created a rarely-seen collaboration by exchanging wild yeast cultures via snail mail and utilizing each other's unique strains. With good reason, most companies, if not all, are intensely protective over their yeast. House yeast cultures are what make a beverage so unique. It's part of what makes their liquid taste like their liquid. Our focus at Graft is on the impact of yeast on our ferments rather than obsessing over apple varieties. ⁠
⁠
By incorporating Botanist and Barrel's proprietary 🧫yeast strain into our fermentation process, we've infused their cider's essence into our cider. The result? A unique ferment featuring blueberries 🫐, blueberry wood 🪵, and blueberry leaves 🍃. The wood imparts a touch of fruitiness and tannin, while the leaves add floral notes reminiscent of dried white tea. ⁠

Native has always been a passion project for us. The sheer amount of resources it takes us to source, press, ferment, age, and condition this spontaneous natural cider is more than you would think.⁠
⁠
Over the past few years, you have seen us come out with some pretty crazy things like guava kiwi slushie cider, apricot mochi cider, hopped lactose dreamsicles, and coffee chocolate mead ciders that definitely gave us a bit of Fourloko energy. Maybe it's just us gracefully aging into our 30’s, but we’ve decided to move away from the nostalgia and deserty-flavored ciders.⁠
⁠
We are moving into a new era here at Graft. Literally, our new 16,000sq ft facility will allow us to process more raw ingredients. Our new box truck will allow us to pick fruit from local farms in bulk. And some of our new friendships are allowing us to bolster our barrel program.⁠
⁠
Which brings us to NEW YEAR ROUND NATIVE! Native is our homage to natural cider making, fermented exclusively with Hudson Valley fruit and fermented with native yeast and bacteria living on the apple skins. We then aged the juice in barrels and blended with our foeder using traditional blending methods. Native is light-bodied and rustic, with all the quirks of natural wine. Slow down, take a sip and stay tuned!⁠

Psst, Native should be in stores near you now. 
⁠
#Native #GraftCider #Spontaneousnaturalcider #slowdown #barrelaged #wild #HudsonValley

We cannot tell you the amount of fun we had making Obsidian Fields, our first-ever Blackberry Blood Orange Amaro Cider. The sheer amount of roots, herbs, and flowers that went into making this cider would blow your mind. Each ingredient was carefully chosen to contribute to the complex flavor profile of this unique cider.⁠ 

6.9%ABV- Book of Nomad Series
⁠
What you need to know is that we could not physically fit all of the ingredients it takes to make the bitter-infused Demerara syrup on the label. However, we can list a few: lavender, palo santo wood, ashwagandha root, thyme, fennel, blood orange peel, Angelica root, Orris root, and American oak powder. ⁠
⁠
Once the dry ingredients were mixed, we blended in a house-made simple syrup to soak in the flavors over time. After a month of aging, we steeped the connection in our still for maximum flavor extraction. From here, we blended the finished cider with the bitters-infused simple syrup.⁠
⁠
Altogether, this cider is an amalgamation of flavors. The predominant ingredients in this Amaro cider are NY Apples, Blackberries - to give the cider a deep hue and a touch of fruity sweetness, Blood Orange - a dash of citrus, Bitters Infused Demerara Syrup - bittering and herbal nose and taste, and Thyme for an earthy, minty, slightly lemony flavor.⁠
⁠
As you take your first sip of Obsidian Fields, you'll be greeted by a woodsy, lemony flavor that gradually transforms into the tartness of blackberry jam. But just when you think you've tasted it all, the finish surprises you with a dry, bitter, tannic taste. The lingering tannins on your tongue create a thirst for more, while a hint of sweetness keeps everything in perfect balance.⁠
⁠
We could go on and on, it may be easier for you to grab a can and try it yourself :)⁠

💎NOUVEAU RICHE💎⁠
🍒 a carbonic cherry wine cider⁠
Graft x @HoofHeartedBrewing⁠
⁠
6.9% abv • ⁠ 3g sugar • ⁠ 160 calories • ⁠ Gluten Free⁠
⁠
Nouveau Riche, a shared Universe collaboration, is born out of mutual love for natural wines and funky fruit fermentations. Deliciously juicy and elevated in flavor, this nontraditional style is hella nouveau rich and spits🌬️ in the face of convention.⁠
⁠
Made from New York apples, sour Engish Morello cherries, and white wine concentrate, this boujee bae tastes like 🍒Sour Cherries, 🍇Natural Cherry Wine, Basque cider🍎.

We decided to approach NY-grown English Morello cherries in the same fashion that wine grapes are treated by fermenting using a technique called carbonic maceration.

Carbonic maceration creates esters (fruity-smelling chemical compounds) that give certain unmistakable flavors to red wines and, in our case, cherries.

During the carbonic maceration processes, the entire cherry was fermented until the skins burst inside the tank. 400LBS of cherries to be exact. We then took this spontaneously fermented cherry juice and blended California white wine concentrate with champagne yeast, wild yeast, and bacteria to enhance the natural wine characteristics found in this style of wine.

Finally, the ferment was finished off by blending in barrel-aged New York cider. ⁠

First Forging, a Cherry Bergamot Amaro Cider that'll change the way you see cider, is now available in stores.⁠
⁠
⁠
When you think of cider, you might not associate it with bittering herbs and roots. But we'd like to challenge your perception of what cider can be.⁠
⁠
⁠
So, you may be asking, "What is an Amaro cider? And how is it even possible?"⁠
⁠
⁠
Here's the thing — we don't follow the same exact process as a traditional amaro. Instead of distilling, we ferment. Instead of using spirits, our base is pressed apple juice. But in the end, after our final blend, we're left with a liquid that bears a striking resemblance to its amaro counterpart: a delightful mix of bitter and herbal infusions in alcohol.⁠
⁠

🤯 For one whole month, we soaked Rooibos Tea, Hawthorn berry, Bitter mellon peel, Quinine bark, Yerba Mate, Gentian Root, Meadowsweet, Makrut Lime Leaf, Yarrow, Wormwood, Thyme, Marjoram, Ground fennel, Dried Lemon Peel, Chamomile Tea, Organic Pu'erh White Tea, Angelica Root, Blood orange peel, Bergamot peel, Grains of paradise in Demerara Sugar.⁠
⁠
⁠
Once the month was up, the sugar transformed into an earthen brown, tasting like a bitter tea with a bright citrus kick, yet super sweet from the demerara sugar. A tartness from the rooibos and Makrut Leaf was present, along with a deep richness from the Gentian Root and Grains of paradise.

⁠We steeped this concoction in our still to extract every bit of flavor. From there, we blended the finished cider (NY Apples, Cherry, and Orange Bergamot) with the bitters-infused simple syrup.⁠
⁠
First Foraging is complex enough to drink independently, yet simple enough to pair with dinner.⁠
⁠
Cheers!⁠

We are beyond excited to release the first drop of Oranje, a natural spontaneous orange wine cider. 6.9%ABV

This cider is part of our Native - limited release series and will only be released a few times per year. 

So how’d we do it?

We spontaneously fermented Finger Lake Riseling grape skins with Hudson Valley Apples, creating a hyper-local blend. The spent Riesling skins aged for three weeks, co-fermenting with the juice and imparting its color and wine-like flavor into the blend. We then blended barrel aged cider with the Oranje wine, canned it, then let the cider condition in the can.

Native Oranje is light-bodied, joyfully effervescent with notes of rose petals and lychee, texturally similar to white. This natural wine cider is bright, crisp and refreshing with touches of funk and hay.

In 6 months we will be releasing a aged bottle version!

Slow down, take a sip, and let the flavors tell their story.

Believe it or not, we didn't plan to incorporate on Halloween. But, looking back, it seems quite apt for our theatrical, adventurous, and perpetually in-motion minds that operate GRAFT.

Rewinding from 2023 to our humble beginnings in 2016 (don't forget to swipe!), we've crafted an astonishing variety of series. From Dreamsicles to Imperial barrel-aged ciders, Mochi ciders, and Cocktail ciders, we've done it all. We've even had the pleasure of collaborating with some of our favorite breweries, cideries, and wineries - anyone remember the Worlds Apart and Worlds Collide x @revelcider & collaborated with some of our fav restaurants like @bloominghillfarm for Book of Nomad dinners.

Our journey has been nothing short of extraordinary. From the illicit pop-ups we used to host, we've grown into a brand new 16,000 sqft production facility this year.

We've evolved from our very first unlabeled bottle of Native to mass-producing printed cans for our core line (industry insiders know the sheer volume of cans needed to justify a printed order - it's staggering!).

The overwhelming support you've shown for our online store and Cider Club never ceases to amaze us.

We're truly grateful for the recognition we've received from @imbibe, @hopculturemag, and journalists like @joshmbernstein who tirelessly champion the cause of cider.

Creating innovative and exciting ciders for you has been the thrill of a lifetime. A heartfelt thank you to everyone who has supported us and continues to do so.

Native cider pressing and fermentation are in full swing for 2024, and we have an amazing amount of natural wine-inspired ciders in the pipeline!

In the container are the spent pomace and grape skins from our most recent round of pressing; we sourced Hudson Valley grown cider apples and different wine grapes from the Finger Lakes, such as Chambourcin and Riesling.  This project is about fermenting the different agricultural fruits from the ny region and expressing them naturally through spontaneous fermentation and low-intervention winemaking methods. 

Looking closely at the spent fruit skins, you can see it's already breaking down and fermenting from the stream coming off it.  We will harness this and convert the cider into compost instead of being discarded as waste. This nutrient-rich compost will later enrich the soil of the taproom space, transforming it into a vibrant green area. The taproot is set to open in 2024, marking a new chapter in the journey.

Introducing Native Oranje, our unique take on an orange wine, but in cider form. This specialty is part of our limited 'Native' series and will only be released a few times per year.⁠
⁠
⁠
You may have heard of Orange Wine. What we are making here follows a similar process, but with a twist - we're also using apples.⁠
⁠
⁠
An Orange wine - and in our case, an Orange cider - is created by aging white wine grapes with their skins. For this blend, we used Finger Lakes Riesling skins.⁠
⁠
⁠
So, why do wine grape skins play such a significant role? Here's why:⁠
⁠
⁠
1. Color: The skins transform the liquid from a straw color to a rich, coppery-orange.⁠
⁠
2. Flavor: Each grape varietal has its own distinct notes and aromas, which become more prominent when included in the aging process.⁠
⁠
3. Texture: The tannins within the skins enhance the mouthfeel of the cider.⁠
⁠
⁠
Now, let's walk through our process:⁠
⁠
We spontaneously fermented Finger Lake Riesling grape skins with Hudson Valley Apples, creating a hyper-local blend. The spent Riesling skins aged for three weeks, co-fermenting with the juice. This process imparts color and wine-like flavor into the blend, thanks to the native yeast & bacteria.⁠
⁠
⁠
Next, we blended the result with barrel-aged cider and Oranje wine, then canned it, allowing the cider to condition within the can.⁠
⁠
⁠
The result? Native Oranje. It's light-bodied, joyfully effervescent, with notes of rose petals and lychee, and its texture is akin to white wine. This natural wine cider is bright, crisp, and refreshing, with touches of funk and hay.⁠
⁠
⁠
In six months, we will be releasing an aged bottle version!⁠
⁠
Be sure to check out the stores that carry our limited series for a chance to experience Native Oranje.⁠
⁠

"Links that Bind" marks the conclusion of our Fall Amaro cider series. This Raspberry Bitter Orange Amaro Cider delivers a distinctive flavor profile, drawing parallels to an Amaro sherbet, subtly infused with warming spices and a dash of Chambord.⁠
⁠
Its unique taste is achieved by soaking roots, herbs, and spices for a month to create a bitters-infused syrup. Warming spices like nutmeg, allspice, and clove are added, with bitter orange peel and wormwood introducing bitterness. This is balanced by cocoa powder and Demerara sugar's sweetness. Sumac, sage powder, and rooibos add depth, while a variety of roots like Angelica, marshmallow, sarsaparilla, and chicory contribute complexity.

"Links that Bind" provides an unrivaled cider experience, reflecting the creativity and craftsmanship that defines our Fall Amaro cider series with its complex, carefully curated blend of flavors. 6.9% ABV⁠

It feels like it's been forever since we last talked about Farm Flor.⁠
⁠
⁠
Farm Flor truly embodies the environment and agriculture surrounding us. The apples we use are sourced from @minards_family_farms, located just 30 minutes north of us. ⁠
⁠
⁠
Pressed and delivered to us, the juice doesn't have to travel far before it starts fermenting. This means the juice doesn't undergo a lot of physical agitation from sloshing around, nor does it experience extreme temperature changes during transportation.⁠
⁠
⁠
Fermentation is simple, using only the wild yeast and bacteria naturally found on the skin of the apples. We blend this with an in-house wood tea steeped from Spanish Cedar, American Oak, and French Oak. This is then blended further with cider aged in a fouder. ⁠
⁠
Farm Flor is complex enough to be enjoyed on its own yet simple enough to accompany a meal. Farm Flor is rustically dry, bright and funky, with notes of hay, yeast and earth.⁠
At 6.9% ABV, you can have two without feeling wrecked (which we love).⁠
⁠
⁠
Farm Flor is a staple in the Graft lineup, which means it should be readily available everywhere. We never run out of stock.⁠
⁠
⁠
Find it in stores near you using our cider finder or grab it on our online store - link in bio.⁠
⁠

WE BET YOU ALREADY KNOW that each cider in the Book of Nomad series has a story to accompany each flavor. Catch up below to see where Dog and Nomad have been exploring this fall season.⁠
⁠
🌋Ch 1: Obsidian Fields⁠
⁠
Wanting to make some overdue repairs and improvements to his ship, Nomad decides to seek out the powerful Hephaestus for help forging the new parts. Exploring the volcanic planet Etna, at first Nomad and Dog find no signs of the deity, or any civilization for that matter. Eventually, Dog’s ears perk up at the sound of hammers clanging, and they follow the noise to a gigantic roaring lavafall. Fashioning an impromptu umbrella out of the most fire-resistant alloys from his ship, Nomad leads Dog through the falls and discovers Hephaestus’ ancient workshop in the caverns beyond.⁠
⁠
⚒️Ch 2: First Forging⁠
⁠
Upon hearing Nomad’s requests, Hephaestus points out that he has no reason to help a man and dog he’s never met or heard of before. Just to avoid being dismissed then and there, Nomad challenges the deity to a metalworking contest. Hephaestus laughs at the ludicrous idea, but impressed with his confidence, agrees – if Nomad can forge 3 things even half as good as him, he will help with the ship upgrades. As a crowd of gods and men form, Nomad and Hephaestus get to swinging, and the clangs and sizzles of their work echo through the stone halls.⁠
⁠
🔗Ch 3: Links that Bind⁠
⁠
When the bell sounds to signal times-up, it’s clear that Nomad’s work is nowhere near the level of Hephaestus. But looking over his spear, shield, and helm, the god can’t help but admire the mortal’s handiwork. Hephaestus offers a second contest: if Nomad and Dog can make a chainmail hood halfway as quickly as him, he would still help them. With Dog coiling the wire and Nomad cutting and crimping, they are able to succeed at the task. Following the cheers and applause, they shake hands and paws and proceed to work on the space vessel.⁠
⁠
Story, photo, and artwork by triple threat @CalebLukeLin⁠

Step into the Scottish Highlands this month with our Peat Smoked Whiskey Book of Nomad Cider (TRAILS END). 6.9%ABV

A few months ago, we filled whiskey barrels with bittersweet concentrate—a low acid/high tannin cider that adds body and caramel flavor to anything it touches.

While the barrels were aging, we lit up our smoker, being careful not to let the temperature reach over 200°F to avoid accidental caramelization of the demerara sugar. Together, we smoked peat and sugar for an hour, allowing the smoke to engulf all sides of the sugar crystals. Peat imparts flavors and smells like burnt wood and damp soil.

Blending together the smoked sugar, barrel-aged whiskey cider, and fermented Graft cider created this month's Book of Nomad Cider.

It's pretty amazing when simple, high-quality ingredients come together to make a complex and layered flavored cider.

RELEASE DATE - JAN 1 FOR CIDER EXPLORERS - MID JANUARY FOR EVERYONE ELSE.
